Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Cavity-Enhanced Exciton Emission from Carbon Nanotubes in the Intrinsic Regime
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical Description: This collaborative project between Stevens Institute of Technology and Columbia University seeks to understand and control the interaction of light with crystalline matter in nanoscale photonic structures. The research includes material growth of crystalline wires that are only one nanometer in diameter and several micrometers long. These so-called nanowires are then integrated with photonic nanostructures that strongly enhance their light emission. A particular focus is on the fundamental understanding of how electric charges interact with heat and light in these nanoscale structures. Ultimately, this research project enables an efficiency and performance boost for chip-scale light sources and detectors, in particular quantum-light sources that are needed to realize quantum-communication technologies to support, for example, national security. The principal investigators collaborate to introduce new research-based educational materials into the graduate curricula on both campuses by team-teaching these subjects via video link. This project offers research experience to graduate and undergraduate students. Outreach activities at Stevens leverage institutional programs such as the Women in Engineering Program. At Columbia, the co-principal investigator develops an outreach model that builds a close partnership with teachers at the Columbia Secondary School for Math, Science, and Engineering, a public, 6-12 school with a large population of under-represented students.

Technical Description: Carbon nanotubes have recently gained tremendous interest as a nanomaterial for the next-generation optoelectronics and quantum photonic devices. To date, the majority of experiments revealed, however, low quantum efficiencies due to extrinsic interactions with the environment that lower the prospects for applications. The collaborative project takes advantage of an ultra-narrow spectral linewidth regime featuring intrinsic spontaneous light emission rates and prolonged exciton dephasing in ultraclean carbon nanotubes, and integrates them with optical cavities. Specifically, the research objectives are (1) to dramatically enhance the light collection as well as the optical emission rate of carbon nanotubes in order to demonstrate efficient on-chip quantum light sources and (2) to uncover the intrinsic exciton dephasing mechanism and acoustic-phonon localization effects. The technical approach explores methods to integrate carbon nanotubes with metallo-dielectric antennas and plasmonic nanocavities, and to further engineer the exciton dephasing via manipulation of the acoustic-phonon density of states. The project advances the understanding of fundamental light-matter interaction in carbon nanotubes, in particular in the presence of localized excitons and phonons along the nanotubes and contributes to advances in on-chip quantum photonics and cavity-optomechanics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Carbon nanotubes are promising absorbers and emitters for optoelectronic and quantum photonic devices. In this program two research teams lead by Strauf at Stevens and by Hone at Columbia collaborated with the goal to integrate ultra-clean carbon nanotubes into nanoplasmonic cavities. The research objectives were to dramatically enhance the light collection as well as the optical emission rate of carbon nanotubes in order to demonstrate efficient on-chip quantum light sources. These objectives were accomplished by design and nanofabrication of bowtie nanoantenna arrays with 10 nm small gap size that have been integrated with carbon nanotubes and characterized for their photophysical properties. Beyond carbon nanotubes the collaborative work has also explored alternative materials such as two-dimensional monolayers of semiconducting material and demonstrated new ways to create quantum emitters in 2D materials. The following lists some key outcomes of this program with respect to efficiency and performance advances of on-chip single photon sources:

(1) We demonstrated carbon nanotube excitons coupled to dense arrays of plasmonic nanocavities reaching deeply into the Purcell regime with FP = 180, resulting in a record-high single-photon emission rates of 15 MHz into the first lens. The cavity-enhanced quantum yield of 62% is the highest reported for carbon nanotubes and a significant improvement over previous work (2%), making this material system more suitable for optoelectronic device applications.

(2) We demonstrated for the first time that it is possible to measure plasmonic heat at the nanoscale with a single molecule. The demonstrated utility of polyfluorene wrapped carbon nanotubes operating as single-molecule thermometers with all-optical read out has uncovered a unique interplay of excitons, phonons, and plasmons at the nanoscale.

(3) Another outcome is a passivation technique based on high-quality atomic-layer-deposition grown aluminum oxide layers that avoids detrimental spectral diffusion of quantum emitters. Record-narrow exciton linewidths have been demonstrated for the exciton emission from carbon nanotubes (18 micro eV linewidth) that reach the radiative limit for the first time. This enables frequency-stable quantum light sources. 

(4) Another key outcome is related to covalently functionalized carbon nanotubes and their dependence on solvent as well as dispersant. It was demonstrated that 3,5-dichlorobenzene quantum defects in carbon nanotubes that were wrapped into the co-polymer polyfluorene are 5-fold better protected against pump-induced dephasing as compared to regular carbon nanotubes. 
  

(5) In parallel efforts, the collaborative work explored two-dimensional materials that could become an alternative quantum emitter platform to the currently utilized carbon nanotubes. It was found that quantum emitters can be formed due to the underlying strain field of local nanobubbles at the interface of monolayer tungsten di-selenide and boron nitride. Techniques were developed to either intentionally create or entirely avoid nanobubble induced quantum emitters. 

Broader Impacts: The reported findings particularly on cavity-enhanced quantum yield advance a broad range of optoelectronic devices and enable an efficiency and performance boost for nanoscale light emitting diodes and single photon sources that are affected by the photophysics in carbon nanotubes. Research carried out in this project benefits society by impacting future secure quantum communication technologies required for improving national security and furthermore advances energy efficient light sources that will have a positive impact on the environment due to lower power consumption. Funding provided by this award helped building and strengthening a core research unit that continues to attract, educate, and train students in STEM disciplines. The supported graduate students worked in a truly interdisciplinary research environment, received clean room training by professional staff at the CUNY/ASRC facility, and disseminated their research at international conferences. The program also provided mentoring as well as hands-on experience for 2 undergraduates during the academic year and 2 high school students from an economically disadvantaged backgrounds over summers, thereby expanding their education and career outlook. These high school students, including one WESEF Science Fair winner, disseminated the research in this program to several high school teachers and students.
